content:
TITLE: Playing Chess with Stockfish using SimpleEngine in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to play chess using the Stockfish engine with the SimpleEngine class for synchronous execution. It initializes the engine, plays moves until the game is over, and then quits the engine. The Limit class is used to set a time limit for each move.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/engine.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import chess
import chess.engine

engine = chess.engine.SimpleEngine.popen_uci(r"C:\Users\xxxxx\Downloads\stockfish_14_win_x64\stockfish_14_win_x64_avx2.exe")

board = chess.Board()
while not board.is_game_over():
    result = engine.play(board, chess.engine.Limit(time=0.1))
    board.push(result.move)

engine.quit()
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Exporting a Game to PGN Format in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to create a chess game object, add headers and variations (moves and comments), and then print the game in PGN (Portable Game Notation) format. It uses the chess and chess.pgn modules. The output includes headers such as Event, Site, Date, Round, White, Black, and Result, followed by the move list with a comment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/pgn.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import chess
import chess.pgn

game = chess.pgn.Game()
game.headers["Event"] = "Example"
node = game.add_variation(chess.Move.from_uci("e2e4"))
node = node.add_variation(chess.Move.from_uci("e7e5"))
node.comment = "Comment"

print(game)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Analyzing a Chess Position with SimpleEngine in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to analyse a chess position using the SimpleEngine class for synchronous execution. It initializes the engine, analyses a board, prints the score, analyses another board with a specified depth, prints the score, and then quits the engine. The Limit class is used to set a time or depth limit for the analysis.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/engine.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import chess
import chess.engine

engine = chess.engine.SimpleEngine.popen_uci("/usr/bin/stockfish")

board = chess.Board()
info = engine.analyse(board, chess.engine.Limit(time=0.1))
print("Score:", info["score"])
# Score: PovScore(Cp(+20), WHITE)

board = chess.Board("r1bqkbnr/p1pp1ppp/1pn5/4p3/2B1P3/5Q2/PPPP1PPP/RNB1K1NR w KQkq - 2 4")
info = engine.analyse(board, chess.engine.Limit(depth=20))
print("Score:", info["score"])
# Score: PovScore(Mate(+1), WHITE)

engine.quit()
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Analyzing a Chess Position with asyncio in Python
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates asynchronous analysis of chess positions using asyncio. It initializes the engine with popen_uci within an asyncio event loop, analyses a board, prints the score, analyses another board with a specified depth, prints the score, and then quits the engine. The Limit class is used to limit the time or depth of analysis.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/engine.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import asyncio
import chess
import chess.engine

async def main() -> None:
    transport, engine = await chess.engine.popen_uci("/usr/bin/stockfish")

    board = chess.Board()
    info = await engine.analyse(board, chess.engine.Limit(time=0.1))
    print(info["score"])
    # Score: PovScore(Cp(+20), WHITE)

    board = chess.Board("r1bqkbnr/p1pp1ppp/1pn5/4p3/2B1P3/5Q2/PPPP1PPP/RNB1K1NR w KQkq - 2 4")
    info = await engine.analyse(board, chess.engine.Limit(depth=20))
    print(info["score"])
    # Score: PovScore(Mate(+1), WHITE)

    await engine.quit()

asyncio.run(main())
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Writing a Game to File in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code shows how to write a chess game in PGN format to a file.  It uses the `file` argument in the `print` function to specify the output file. The `end` parameter is set to "\n\n" to separate games in the file with extra blank lines as per PGN standard. The example writes to `/dev/null`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/pgn.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
print(game, file=open("/dev/null", "w"), end="\n\n")
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Indefinite Analysis with asyncio in Python
DESCRIPTION: This example illustrates indefinite chess engine analysis using asyncio. It initializes the engine and streams analysis information asynchronously. The loop breaks based on an arbitrary condition, specifically when the selective search depth exceeds 20.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/engine.rst#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import asyncio
import chess
import chess.engine

async def main() -> None:
    transport, engine = await chess.engine.popen_uci("/usr/bin/stockfish")

    with await engine.analysis(chess.Board()) as analysis:
        async for info in analysis:
            print(info.get("score"), info.get("pv"))

            # Arbitrary stop condition.
            if info.get("seldepth", 0) > 20:
                break

        await engine.quit()

asyncio.run(main())
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using the Tablebase Class in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: The `chess.syzygy.Tablebase` class provides an interface to query the opened Syzygy tablebase. It contains members that allow access to the WDL and DTZ information for a given position. Ensure that the tablebase files match the known checksums for security.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/syzygy.rst#_snippet_1



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Indefinite Analysis with SimpleEngine in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases indefinite chess engine analysis using SimpleEngine for synchronous execution. It starts an analysis stream and iterates through the information provided by the engine. The analysis is stopped based on an arbitrary condition related to the search depth.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/engine.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import chess
import chess.engine

engine = chess.engine.SimpleEngine.popen_uci("/usr/bin/stockfish")

with engine.analysis(chess.Board()) as analysis:
    for info in analysis:
        print(info.get("score"), info.get("pv"))

        # Arbitrary stop condition.
        if info.get("seldepth", 0) > 20:
            break

engine.quit()
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Integrating with UCI Engine for Racing Kings in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to integrate a python-chess RacingKingsBoard with a UCI engine (Stockfish in this case). It initializes a RacingKingsBoard, starts a UCI engine process, and then plays a move on the board using the engine with a time limit of 1 second.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/variant.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import chess.engine

engine = chess.engine.SimpleEngine.popen_uci("stockfish-mv")

board = chess.variant.RacingKingsBoard()
result = engine.play(board, chess.engine.Limit(time=1.0))
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Engine Options with asyncio in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code shows how to configure options for a chess engine using asyncio. It connects to the engine, prints the available options (specifically 'Hash'), then sets the 'Hash' option to 32 using the configure method. This affects engine behaviour during analysis or gameplay.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/engine.rst#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import asyncio
import chess.engine

async def main() -> None:
    transport, engine = await chess.engine.popen_uci("/usr/bin/stockfish")

    # Check available options.
    print(engine.options["Hash"])
    # Option(name='Hash', type='spin', default=16, min=1, max=131072, var=[])

    # Set an option.
    await engine.configure({"Hash": 32})

    # [...]

asyncio.run(main())
```

TITLE: PGN Parsing with Error Handling - Python
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to use the `chess.pgn.read_game()` function with and without error handling. Demonstrates how a ValueError is raised by default when illegal moves are encountered, and how providing an error_handler allows for silent error ignoring.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_21

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> # Raises ValueError:
>>> game = chess.pgn.read_game(file_with_illegal_moves)
```

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> # Silently ignores errors and continues parsing:
```

TITLE: Opening Syzygy Tablebase in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: This function `chess.syzygy.open_tablebase` opens a Syzygy tablebase file. It is necessary to have the Syzygy tablebase files available locally. The function returns a Tablebase object that can be used to query the tablebase.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/syzygy.rst#_snippet_0



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Creating a Board from EPD - Python
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to create a `chess.Board` object from an Extended Position Description (EPD) string using `chess.Board.from_epd()`. It returns a tuple containing the board and a dictionary of EPD operations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> board, ops = chess.Board.from_epd("4k3/8/8/8/8/8/8/4K3 b - - fmvn 17; hmvc 13")
>>> board
Board('4k3/8/8/8/8/8/8/4K3 b - - 13 17')
>>> ops
{'fmvn': 17, 'hmvc': 13}
```

TITLE: Initializing Chess960 Board in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to initialize a standard chess board with the Chess960 variant enabled. The chess960 parameter is set to True, indicating that the board should be initialized with a random starting position according to Chess960 rules.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/variant.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
chess.Board(chess960=True)
```

TITLE: Memory Mapped Reader in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: The `MemoryMappedReader` class provides an efficient way to read large Polyglot opening books by memory mapping the file. This avoids loading the entire book into memory at once, making it suitable for larger book files and resource-constrained environments.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/polyglot.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
.. autoclass:: chess.polyglot.MemoryMappedReader
    :members:
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Communicating with UCI Engines in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to communicate with UCI (Universal Chess Interface) engines using the python-chess library. It uses the `chess.engine.SimpleEngine.popen_uci` function to start an engine, the `play` method to play a move, and `quit` to terminate the engine process. Requires an executable 'stockfish' in the path.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> import chess.engine

>>> engine = chess.engine.SimpleEngine.popen_uci("stockfish")

>>> board = chess.Board("1k1r4/pp1b1R2/3q2pp/4p3/2B5/4Q3/PPP2B2/2K5 b - - 0 1")
>>> limit = chess.engine.Limit(time=2.0)
>>> engine.play(board, limit)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
<PlayResult at ... (move=d6d1, ponder=c1d1, info={...}, draw_offered=False, resigned=False)>

>>> engine.quit()
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Chess Piece Type Constants in Python
DESCRIPTION: Defines constants for representing the different piece types in chess. Each piece type is assigned a unique integer value from 1 to 6, corresponding to Pawn, Knight, Bishop, Rook, Queen, and King respectively.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/core.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
chess.PAWN
```

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
chess.KNIGHT
```

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
chess.BISHOP
```

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
chess.ROOK
```

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
chess.QUEEN
```

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
chess.KING
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Chess Game Example in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates a basic chess game using the python-chess library, including move generation, move validation, and checking for checkmate.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> import chess

>>> board = chess.Board()

>>> board.legal_moves  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
<LegalMoveGenerator at ... (Nh3, Nf3, Nc3, Na3, h3, g3, f3, e3, d3, c3, ...)>
>>> chess.Move.from_uci("a8a1") in board.legal_moves
False

>>> board.push_san("e4")
Move.from_uci('e2e4')
>>> board.push_san("e5")
Move.from_uci('e7e5')
>>> board.push_san("Qh5")
Move.from_uci('d1h5')
>>> board.push_san("Nc6")
Move.from_uci('b8c6')
>>> board.push_san("Bc4")
Move.from_uci('f1c4')
>>> board.push_san("Nf6")
Move.from_uci('g8f6')
>>> board.push_san("Qxf7")
Move.from_uci('h5f7')

>>> board.is_checkmate()
True

>>> board
Board('r1bqkb1r/pppp1Qpp/2n2n2/4p3/2B1P3/8/PPPP1PPP/RNB1K1NR b KQkq - 0 4')
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Playing Chess with Stockfish using asyncio in Python
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates asynchronous chess play with Stockfish using asyncio. It initializes the engine using popen_uci within an asyncio event loop, then plays moves until the game is over, and finally quits the engine. The Limit class is used to limit the time spent per move.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/engine.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import asyncio
import chess
import chess.engine

async def main() -> None:
    transport, engine = await chess.engine.popen_uci(r"C:\Users\xxxxx\Downloads\stockfish_14_win_x64\stockfish_14_win_x64_avx2.exe")

    board = chess.Board()
    while not board.is_game_over():
        result = await engine.play(board, chess.engine.Limit(time=0.1))
        board.push(result.move)

    await engine.quit()

asyncio.run(main())
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Parsing and Creating FENs in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to parse and create Forsythâ€“Edwards Notation (FEN) strings using the python-chess library. It uses the `fen` and `shredder_fen` methods to create FENs and extended FENs, and `piece_at` to retrieve a piece at a given square.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> board.fen()
'rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1'
>>> board.shredder_fen()
'rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w HAha - 0 1'
>>> board = chess.Board("8/8/8/2k5/4K3/8/8/8 w - - 4 45")
>>> board.piece_at(chess.C5)
Piece.from_symbol('k')
```

TITLE: Adding GPL Notice to Source Files
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to add the GNU General Public License (GPL) notice to the start of each source file in a program.  It includes the program's name, copyright information, and a statement about the GPL license and its terms.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/LICENSE.txt#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
<one line to give the program's name and a brief idea of what it does.>
Copyright (C) <year>  <name of author>

This program is free software: you can redistribute it and/or modify
it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
the Free Software Foundation, either version 3 of the License, or
(at your option) any later version.

This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
GNU General Public License for more details.

You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
along with this program.  If not, see <http://www.gnu.org/licenses/>.
```

TITLE: Reading and Writing PGNs in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to read and write Portable Game Notation (PGN) files using the python-chess library. It uses the `chess.pgn.read_game` function to read a game from a PGN file and access its headers and mainline.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> import chess.pgn

>>> with open("data/pgn/molinari-bordais-1979.pgn") as pgn:
...     first_game = chess.pgn.read_game(pgn)

>>> first_game.headers["White"]
'Molinari'
>>> first_game.headers["Black"]
'Bordais'

>>> first_game.mainline()  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
<Mainline at ... (1. e4 c5 2. c4 Nc6 3. Ne2 Nf6 4. Nbc3 Nb4 5. g3 Nd3#)>

>>> first_game.headers["Result"]
'0-1'
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Polyglot Entry Class in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: The `Entry` class represents a single move entry within a Polyglot opening book. It contains information about the move itself, as well as associated data like weight and learn. This class is fundamental when processing and using opening book suggestions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/polyglot.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
.. autoclass:: chess.polyglot.Entry
    :members:
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Parsing and Creating SAN Moves in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to parse and create Standard Algebraic Notation (SAN) representations of chess moves using the python-chess library. The `san` method converts a move to SAN, and `parse_san` parses a SAN string into a move object.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> board = chess.Board()
>>> board.san(chess.Move(chess.E2, chess.E4))
'e4'
>>> board.parse_san('Nf3')
Move.from_uci('g1f3')
>>> board.variation_san([chess.Move.from_uci(m) for m in ["e2e4", "e7e5", "g1f3"]])
'1. e4 e5 2. Nf3'
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Probing Syzygy Tablebases in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to probe Syzygy endgame tablebases using the python-chess library. The `chess.syzygy.open_tablebase` function opens a tablebase, and `probe_dtz` method returns the distance-to-zero (DTZ) value for a given position.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> import chess.syzygy

>>> tablebase = chess.syzygy.open_tablebase("data/syzygy/regular")

>>> # Black to move is losing in 53 half moves (distance to zero) in this
>>> # KNBvK endgame.
>>> board = chess.Board("8/2K5/4B3/3N4/8/8/4k3/8 b - - 0 1")
>>> tablebase.probe_dtz(board)
-53

>>> tablebase.close()
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Building and Installing libgtb (Gaviota Tablebases)
DESCRIPTION: This shell script clones the Gaviota Tablebases repository, builds the shared library using `make`, and installs it system-wide using `sudo make install`. This provides faster access to tablebase information through the `NativeTablebase` class in the `chess.gaviota` module.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/gaviota.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: Shell
CODE:
```
git clone https://github.com/michiguel/Gaviota-Tablebases.git
cd Gaviota-Tablebases
make
sudo make install
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Displaying ASCII Board in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code shows how to display a simple ASCII representation of a chess board using the python-chess library.  The `chess.Board` class is used to create a board object, and `print(board)` generates the ASCII representation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> board = chess.Board("r1bqkb1r/pppp1Qpp/2n2n2/4p3/2B1P3/8/PPPP1PPP/RNB1K1NR b KQkq - 0 4")
>>> print(board)
r . b q k b . r
p p p p . Q p p
. . n . . n . .
. . . . p . . .
. . B . P . . .
. . . . . . . .
P P P P . P P P
R N B . K . N R
```

TITLE: Displaying GPL Notice in Interactive Terminal Programs
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to display a short GPL notice when a program starts in interactive mode. It includes the program's name, copyright information, a warranty disclaimer, and instructions for viewing the full license details.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/LICENSE.txt#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
<program>  Copyright (C) <year>  <name of author>
This program comes with ABSOLUTELY NO WARRANTY; for details type `show w'.
This is free software, and you are welcome to redistribute it
under certain conditions; type `show c' for details.
```

TITLE: Configuring Engine Options with SimpleEngine in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to configure options for a chess engine using the SimpleEngine class in Python. It checks the available options, then sets a specific option (Hash) to a new value. This configures the engine's behavior.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/engine.rst#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import chess.engine

engine = chess.engine.SimpleEngine.popen_uci("/usr/bin/stockfish")

# Check available options.
engine.options["Hash"]
# Option(name='Hash', type='spin', default=16, min=1, max=131072, var=[])

# Set an option.
engine.configure({"Hash": 32})

# [...]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Accessing Variant Information in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to access variant-specific information from a board object, such as the UCI variant name, the XBoard variant name, and the starting FEN string. These attributes provide metadata about the specific chess variant being played.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/variant.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
type(board).uci_variant
'giveaway'
type(board).xboard_variant
'giveaway'
type(board).starting_fen
'rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w - - 0 1'
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Remote Engine Communication with AsyncSSH in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use AsyncSSH to communicate with a chess engine on a remote computer. It establishes an SSH connection, creates a subprocess running the engine, initializes the engine, and then executes a ping command.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/engine.rst#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import asyncio
import asyncssh
import chess
import chess.engine

async def main() -> None:
    async with asyncssh.connect("localhost") as conn:
        channel, engine = await conn.create_subprocess(chess.engine.UciProtocol, "/usr/bin/stockfish")
        await engine.initialize()

        # Play, analyse, ...
        await engine.ping()

asyncio.run(main())
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Reading Polyglot Opening Books in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to read Polyglot opening books using the python-chess library. It uses the `chess.polyglot.open_reader` function to open a book file and the `find` method to retrieve an entry for a given board position.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> import chess.polyglot

>>> book = chess.polyglot.open_reader("data/polyglot/performance.bin")

>>> board = chess.Board()
>>> main_entry = book.find(board)
>>> main_entry.move
Move.from_uci('e2e4')
>>> main_entry.weight
1

>>> book.close()
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using Syzygy Tablebase for Atomic Chess in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to open and use a Syzygy tablebase for Atomic chess. It imports the necessary modules, opens the tablebase file, specifying the variant board type as AtomicBoard, and then presumably proceeds to use the tablebase for move generation or evaluation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/variant.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import chess.syzygy
import chess.variant

tables = chess.syzygy.open_tablebase("data/syzygy", VariantBoard=chess.variant.AtomicBoard)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Parsing and Creating EPDs in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to parse and create Extended Position Description (EPD) records using the python-chess library.  The `epd` method creates an EPD record, and `set_epd` parses an EPD string.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> board = chess.Board()
>>> board.epd(bm=board.parse_uci("d2d4"))
'rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - bm d4;'
```

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> ops = board.set_epd("1k1r4/pp1b1R2/3q2pp/4p3/2B5/4Q3/PPP2B2/2K5 b - - bm Qd1+; id \"BK.01\";")
>>> ops == {'bm': [chess.Move.from_uci('d6d1')], 'id': 'BK.01'}
True
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Castling Rights Check - Python
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to check castling rights using bitwise operations with `chess.BB_A1`, `chess.BB_H1`, `chess.BB_A8`, `chess.BB_H8` and the `board.castling_rights` attribute. It demonstrates checking for specific castling rights.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_19

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> board = chess.Board()

>>> # Standard castling rights.
>>> board.castling_rights == chess.BB_A1 | chess.BB_H1 | chess.BB_A8 | chess.BB_H8
True

>>> # Check for the presence of a specific castling right.
>>> can_white_castle_queenside = chess.BB_A1 & board.castling_rights
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: UCI InfoHandler Usage - Python
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to access the 'score' information from the `uci.InfoHandler` object within a `with` statement, specifically how to access the centipawn score (cp) from the info dictionary for multipv analysis.  Shows the change needed in the new version.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_20

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> with info_handler as info:
...     if 1 in info["score"]:
...         cp = info["score"][1].cp
```

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> with info_handler as info:
...     if "score" in info:
...         cp = info["score"].cp
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Detecting Game Endings in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to detect checkmates, stalemates, and draws by insufficient material using the python-chess library. It uses methods such as `is_stalemate`, `is_insufficient_material`, and `outcome` to determine the game's ending.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> board.is_stalemate()
False
>>> board.is_insufficient_material()
False
>>> board.outcome()
Outcome(termination=<Termination.CHECKMATE: 1>, winner=True)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Detecting Repetitions in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to detect threefold repetitions and track the half-move clock using the python-chess library. It uses methods like `can_claim_threefold_repetition`, `halfmove_clock`, `can_claim_fifty_moves`, `can_claim_draw`, `is_fivefold_repetition` and `is_seventyfive_moves`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> board.can_claim_threefold_repetition()
False
>>> board.halfmove_clock
0
>>> board.can_claim_fifty_moves()
False
>>> board.can_claim_draw()
False
```

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> board.is_fivefold_repetition()
False
>>> board.is_seventyfive_moves()
False
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Zobrist Hash Function in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: The `zobrist_hash` function calculates the Zobrist hash of a given board position. This hash is used to efficiently index and search for positions in the Polyglot opening book, significantly speeding up the move lookup process.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/polyglot.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
.. autofunction:: chess.polyglot.zobrist_hash
```

TITLE: Enabling Debug Logging for Chess Engine Communication in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to enable debug logging for chess engine communication. This allows developers to see detailed information about the interaction between the chess program and the engine, aiding in debugging and troubleshooting.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/engine.rst#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import logging

# Enable debug logging.
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)
```

TITLE: Opening Polyglot Book Reader in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: The `open_reader` function is used to open a Polyglot opening book file and create a reader object for accessing entries within the book. It is typically the first step when utilizing opening books in a chess engine using python-chess.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/polyglot.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
.. autofunction:: chess.polyglot.open_reader
```

TITLE: Chess Color Constants in Python
DESCRIPTION: Defines constants for representing the two colors in chess: white and black. These constants are boolean values where chess.WHITE is True and chess.BLACK is False. The 'not' operator can be used to get the opposite color.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/core.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
chess.WHITE
```

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
chess.BLACK
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Making and Unmaking Moves in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to make and unmake moves using the python-chess library. It uses the `push` method to make a move and the `pop` method to undo the last move.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> Nf3 = chess.Move.from_uci("g1f3")
>>> board.push(Nf3)  # Make the move

>>> board.pop()  # Unmake the last move
Move.from_uci('g1f3')
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Printing a Bitboard
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to print a human-readable representation of a `chess.Bitboard` object. It utilizes the built-in `print` function to display the board's state.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_24

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> print(chess.Bitboard())
r n b q k b n r
p p p p p p p p
. . . . . . . .
. . . . . . . .
. . . . . . . .
. . . . . . . .
P P P P P P P P
R N B Q K B N R
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Parsing SAN Notation Python
DESCRIPTION: Introduces `chess.pgn.BaseVisitor.parse_san(board, san)` which is used by parsers and can be overwritten to deal with non-standard input formats. This allows greater flexibility in handling different notations for chess moves.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_7



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Generating Knight and Queen Moves in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to generate legal moves for knights and queens using the modified `Board.generate_legal_moves()` method.  It uses bitwise OR to combine the squares occupied by knights and queens.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
board.generate_legal_moves(board.knights | board.queens)
```

TITLE: Initializing an Empty Chess Board - Python
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to initialize an empty chess board using the `chess.Board.empty()` method. This creates a board with no pieces on it, represented by the FEN string '8/8/8/8/8/8/8/8 w - - 0 1'.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_17

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> chess.Board.empty()
Board('8/8/8/8/8/8/8/8 w - - 0 1')
```

TITLE: Initializing a Giveaway Board in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to import the chess.variant module and initialize a GiveawayBoard object. The GiveawayBoard class is used to represent a game of Giveaway chess, also known as Suicide chess or Losing chess.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/variant.rst#_snippet_0

CODE:
```
import chess.variant

board = chess.variant.GiveawayBoard()
```

TITLE: Detecting Checks and Attacks in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to detect checks and attacks using the python-chess library. It uses methods like `is_check`, `is_attacked_by`, and `attackers` to determine if a square is under attack.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/README.rst#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> board.is_check()
True
>>> board.is_attacked_by(chess.WHITE, chess.E8)
True
```

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> attackers = board.attackers(chess.WHITE, chess.F3)
>>> attackers
SquareSet(0x0000_0000_0000_4040)
>>> chess.G2 in attackers
True
>>> print(attackers)
. . . . . . . .
. . . . . . . .
. . . . . . . .
. . . . . . . .
. . . . . . . .
. . . . . . . .
. . . . . . 1 .
. . . . . . 1 .
```

TITLE: Adding Board Color Retrieval Python
DESCRIPTION: Introduces the `Board.color_at(square)` method to retrieve the color of a piece at a given square. This is a new feature in the python-chess library, allowing users to easily determine the color occupying a specific square on the board.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_0



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Adding Move Generation Methods in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: The following new move generation methods are added to the Board class: `Board.generate_pseudo_legal_ep()`, `Board.generate_legal_ep()`, `Board.generate_pseudo_legal_captures()`, `Board.generate_legal_captures()`. They take `from_mask` and `to_mask` parameters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_12



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Modifying Move Generation Methods in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: The signatures of `Board.generate_legal_moves()` and `Board.generate_pseudo_legal_moves()` have been changed to allow selecting arbitrary sets of origin and target squares using `from_mask` and `to_mask` parameters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_9



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Insufficient Material Check Python
DESCRIPTION: Introduces `board.has_insufficient_material(color)` for checking insufficient material for a specific side.  This allows the library to determine if a side has enough material to force a checkmate, an important aspect of chess rules.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_3



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Handling Parsing Errors
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to log errors encountered while parsing a PGN file and continue parsing the game. It passes a logger's exception method to `chess.pgn.read_game`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_23

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> # Logs the error, continues parsing:
>>> game = chess.pgn.read_game(file_with_illegal_moves, logger.exception)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Creating UCI Representations for Moves in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: The `Board.uci(move, chess960=None)` method creates UCI representations for moves in the context of the current position. Unlike `Move.uci()`, it can convert moves in both standard chess and Chess960 modes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_14



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Board Copy with Stack Depth Python
DESCRIPTION: Introduces the `board.copy(stack=depth)` method for creating copies of boards with a limited stack depth. This allows for controlling memory usage when creating copies of game states.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_4



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Board Repetition Check Python
DESCRIPTION: Introduces the `Board.is_repetition(count=3)` method to check if a position has been repeated a specified number of times. This enhances the ability to detect draw conditions in chess games.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_2



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Engine Analysis Result Handling Python
DESCRIPTION: Adds `chess.engine.AnalysisResult.get()` and `empty()` methods for handling analysis results from chess engines. These methods provide ways to access and check the analysis data returned by an engine.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_1



----------------------------------------

TITLE: File Bitboards in Python
DESCRIPTION: Defines constants for bitboards representing each file on the chessboard.  `chess.BB_FILES` is a list containing the bitboards for files A to H.

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
chess.BB_FILES
```

TITLE: Checking for Legal En Passant Moves in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: The `Board.has_legal_en_passant()` method tests if a position has a legal en passant move. This is used to determine if the en passant square should be displayed in the FEN representation.

TITLE: Generating Castling Moves in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to generate only castling moves using `Board.generate_castling_moves()` with `from_mask` and `to_mask` set to `BB_ALL`.

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
Board.generate_castling_moves(from_mask=BB_ALL, to_mask=BB_ALL)
```

TITLE: Reading PGN Game
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates reading a chess game from a PGN file using `chess.pgn.read_game`. It shows how to handle illegal moves during parsing by providing a logger.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/CHANGELOG-OLD.rst#_snippet_22

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> game = chess.pgn.read_game(file_with_illegal_moves, None)
```

TITLE: Initializing Board with Chess960 in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: The `Board` constructor now accepts a `chess960` argument, defaulting to `False`. The `Board.chess960` property indicates whether the board is in Chess960 mode.

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Creating SVG Arrows Python
DESCRIPTION: Enhanced `chess.svg.Arrow(tail, head, color="#888")` by adding optional color argument.  This enhances the visual customization of board representations in SVG format.

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Board Transformation Python
DESCRIPTION: Introduces `board.apply_transform(f)` and `board.transform(f)` for applying bitboard transformations to a position. The library provides example transformations like `chess.flip_{vertical,horizontal,diagonal,anti_diagonal}`.

DESCRIPTION: Defines a constant representing a full bitboard, where all squares are set. This bitboard has a value of 0xFFFF_FFFF_FFFF_FFFF.

CODE:
```
chess.BB_ALL
```

TITLE: Polyglot Random Array in Python Chess
DESCRIPTION: The `POLYGLOT_RANDOM_ARRAY` is a list of 781 pseudo-random values used for Zobrist hashing in Polyglot books.  These values are essential for quickly calculating hash keys for board positions, enabling efficient lookup of moves in the opening book.
SOURCE: https://github.com/niklasf/python-chess/blob/master/docs/polyglot.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```

    :value: [0x9D39247E33776D41, ..., 0xF8D626AAAF278509]
```

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
chess.BB_CORNERS
```
